name: GrantGuru AI
description: An agentic LLM platform that helps researchers automatically generate full grant proposals. It reads funding agency guidelines, extracts key eligibility and formatting rules, parses the researcher’s CV and prior grant data, suggests a compelling narrative, and builds detailed budgeting tables, delivering a ready‑to‑submit PDF or Word document.

tools.name: fetch_guidelines
tools.description: Retrieves the official funding agency guidelines for a specified grant program and returns the relevant sections (eligibility, format, budget limits) as Markdown.

agency_name.description: Name of the funding agency, e.g., "NIH" or "NSF".

program_id.description: Identifier or exact name of the grant program, e.g., "R01".

tools.name: parse_cv
tools.description: Analyzes a researcher’s CV (PDF or plain text) and extracts structured data such as education, positions, publications, previous grants, and awards.

cv_content.description: Base64‑encoded content of the CV file or plain‑text CV.

tools.name: search_prior_grants
tools.description: Queries an internal database of previously funded grants to find examples that match a given research area, methodology, or funding amount.

keywords.description: List of keywords describing the project (e.g., "CRISPR", "cancer immunotherapy").

max_results.description: Maximum number of prior grant records to return.

tools.name: generate_budget_table
tools.description: Creates a detailed budgeting spreadsheet (as CSV) based on user‑provided cost items, funding limits, and institution overhead rules.

cost_items.description: List of all budget line items.

tools.name: draft_section
tools.description: Generates a prose draft for a specific grant section (e.g., Significance, Approach) based on supplied bullet points and guidelines.

section_name.description: Name of the grant section to draft.

bullets.description: Key points the user wants to convey in this section.

guidelines_snippet.description: Relevant excerpt from the funding guidelines that constrains the section.

tools.name: assemble_proposal
tools.description: Combines drafted sections, the formatted budget table, and optional appendices into a single PDF or Word document.

sections.description: Mapping from section name to drafted text.

budget_csv.description: CSV string of the budget table produced by generate_budget_table.

examples.description: User requests a full NIH R01 proposal; the assistant pulls guidelines, parses CV, finds similar prior grants, drafts narrative, builds a budget, and returns a ready‑to‑submit PDF.

messages.content: You are GrantGuru AI, an expert grant‑writing assistant. Use the provided tools to gather information, draft sections, and assemble a complete proposal.
I need to submit an NIH R01 for my project on novel CRISPR gene‑editing therapies for glioblastoma. I’ve attached my CV (base64) and a 200‑word abstract. Please produce a full proposal draft.
Got it. I’ll start by fetching the NIH R01 guidelines, then parse your CV, and look for prior successful R01s in a similar area.

## NIH R01 Guidelines (excerpt)
- **Eligibility**: Must have a Ph.D. and ≤5 prior NIH grants.
- **Project Period**: 3–5 years.
- **Budget**: Up to $500,000 direct costs per year, plus 8% overhead.
- **Sections Required**: Specific Aims, Research Strategy (Significance, Innovation, Approach), Bibliography, Budget.
- **Page Limits**: Specific Aims – 1 page; Research Strategy – 12 pages.

messages.content:
### Specific Aims
The overall goal of this proposal is to create a highly specific CRISPR‑based therapeutic platform for glioblastoma. **Aim 1:** Develop a CRISPR‑mediated strategy to selectively ablate glioblastoma stem cells. **Aim 2:** Validate the efficacy and specificity of the platform in vitro. **Aim 3:** Demonstrate therapeutic benefit in orthotopic mouse models of glioblastoma.

### Research Strategy – Approach
**Significance**: Glioblastoma remains lethal despite aggressive treatment; targeting cancer stem cells offers a promising avenue.

**Innovation**: We will combine high‑fidelity Cas9 variants with tumor‑specific guide RNAs, a novel combination not previously tested in GBM.

**Methodology**:
- *Aim 1*: Design and synthesize guide RNAs against CD133 and SOX2. Test editing efficiency in GBM cell lines using T7E1 assay and deep sequencing.
- *Aim 2*: Perform RNA‑seq post‑editing to evaluate off‑target transcriptional changes. Optimize lipid nanoparticle delivery to improve cell-type specificity.
- *Aim 3*: Implant edited GBM cells into immunocompromised mice; monitor tumor growth via MRI and assess survival benefit.

Potential pitfalls include delivery inefficiency and off‑target effects; we will mitigate these with iterative guide RNA redesign and employing high‑fidelity Cas9.
All sections drafted. I will now assemble the final proposal.

- *Aim 2*: Perform RNA‑seq post‑editing to evaluate off‑target transcriptional changes. Optimize lipid nanoparticle delivery to improve cell-type specificity.
- *Aim 3*: Implant edited GBM cells into immunocompromised mice; monitor tumor growth via MRI and assess survival benefit.

Potential pitfalls include delivery inefficiency and off‑target effects; we will mitigate these with iterative guide RNA redesign and employing high‑fidelity Cas9.
